column1: Owls Fall in Waning Seconds to UConn, 48-45
column2: BOCA RATON, Fla. – In a game featuring nearly 1,300 yards of combined offense and four second half lead changes, the Florida Atlantic football team fell just short to UConn on Saturday evening at Flagler Credit Union Stadium, 48-45. The Owls' (4-7) 300th game in program history came down to each team's final drive, but the Huskies (9-4) held on for the three-point win. VIDEO RECAP FIRST HALF After trading field goals on each team's respective first possession, UConn scored touchdowns on its next three opening-quarter series to take a 24-3 lead. To start the second, FAU redshirt junior QB Caden Veltkamp made good on two passes before giving it off to redshirt junior WR Easton Messer for a 39-yard rushing touchdown. After forcing a Huskies punt, Veltkamp capped off a drive by taking it in himself, going head over heels into the end zone for a 17-yard score to make it a one-possession game at 24-17. UConn would add a late field goal to take a 27-17 lead into the locker room. SECOND HALF The Owls' momentum carried over into the third quarter, with back-to-back touchdowns to pull ahead for the first time. The first was a rushing score from 11 yards out by sophomore RB Kaden Shields-Dutton; the second, on 4th-and-1 from their own 10, saw Veltkamp hit redshirt junior wideout Dominique Henry in stride on a quick slant, and he took it 90 yards to put FAU up 31-27. UConn regained the advantage on two straight scores of its own, and led 41-31 with 10:11 to go in the game. But the Owls fought back once again. With 7:13 left, on 4th-and-11, Veltkamp found Messer over the middle for a 33-yard touchdown, and five minutes later, Veltkamp scampered into the end zone for his second rushing score of the game, from 11 yards out. With 2:11 left, FAU led 45-41. On the ensuing possession, the Huskies put together a 15-play, 75-yard drive for the fourth lead change of the second half. The Owls got the ball back with 22 seconds left, and Veltkamp marched the Owls into field goal range with two quick first-down completions. But the game-tying field goal attempt from 36 yards at the horn was wide left, and UConn survived. OFFENSE Veltkamp finished the game 42-for-55 for 494 yards. He set the single-game completion record for the second straight week and is now the new single-game record holder for passing yards in a game, previously set in 2019. He also now holds the new single-season record for completions (previously 291, he now sits at 326), and went over 3,000 yards, the fourth such instance in a season (3,458, now third in history). For the first time in school history, FAU had three receivers with 100 or more yards in a game. Henry (7 catches for 157 yards – both career highs and his first 100-yard game), Messer (11 for 119) and redshirt sophomore Asaad Wassem (12 for 109 – like Henry, new career best and also his first 100-yard game) all went over the century mark. Veltkamp and Henry's 90-yard connection is the third-longest pass in school history. Messer is the first non-QB in FAU history to have a passing, rushing and receiving touchdown in the same season. Shields-Dutton led the backs with 77 yards on 14 carries, followed by redshirt sophomore Gemari Sands' 44 yards on 11 totes. DEFENSE Leading the way in tackles was junior LB Leon Hart Jr. with nine stops. He now has 101 tackles in his career. Just behind him with seven apiece were two DBs, redshirt senior Terez Reid and redshirt junior Jayden Sweeney. Freshman DE Josh Roberts had a solo sack, and splitting the other was redshirt senior DT Bryce Langston and redshirt senior DL Naejaun Barber. POSTGAME AUDIO Hagerty Family Head Football Coach Zach Kittley Redshirt junior quarterback Caden Veltkamp Redshirt sophomore wide receiver Asaad Waseem Redshirt junior linebacker Leon Hart Jr. Redshirt freshman defensive lineman Josh Roberts PHOTO GALLERY UP NEXT Florida Atlantic has its final game of the 2025 regular season next Saturday, Nov. 29, at Flagler Credit Union Stadium, hosting East Carolina. Kickoff is set for noon, and the game will be streamed on ESPN+. FOLLOW ON SOCIAL Stay informed by reading FAUSports.com or through social media accounts @FAUFootball.

column1: Owls Fall in Hard-Fought Battle to Florida
column2: BOCA RATON, Fla. – The Florida Atlantic women's basketball team battled closely with Florida but were unable to hold on through the end of the game, dropping the contest 59-51 inside Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. The Owls fall to 2-3 while Florida improves to 6-1 on the season. HOW IT HAPPENED The Owls had a slow start to the first quarter, with their first points coming from Destyne Jackson three minutes in. This was followed up by a Vivian Onugha layup to make the score 6-4 with 4:12 to go. Florida went on a 6-0 run before a Jess Moors jumper closed out the quarter, with FAU trailing by six, 14-8. The Gators started to pull away at the start of the second, putting the Owls down by 10. Jackson brought FAU back within five points and started a 9-0 run for the Owls, allowing them to bring the score to 18-17. Florida Atlantic got its first lead of the game from a Michiyah Simmons 3-pointer with three minutes to go in the quarter, 20-19. The Owls led by two, 24-22, with under a minute to play, but the Gators closed the half on a 3-0 run to take a one-point advantage into the halftime break, 25-24. Jackson knocked down a jumper to put the Owls back in front to open the third, 26-25, getting her ninth point of the night. The lead continued going back and forth, with six consecutive lead changes. Florida maintained the lead from the 6:28 mark through the end of the third. The Owls kept it close, ending the third down just five, 44-39. The Gators extended their lead to the largest of the night at 11 at the beginning of the fourth quarter, holding Florida Atlantic scoreless until the 7:15 mark. The Gators pushed their lead back to 11 with 33 seconds to play, but a late rally just wasn't enough to close the gap, as Florida took the 59-51 contest. HEAR FROM HEAD COACH LEANN FREELAND "Really excited about the effort tonight against Florida. They are a very good team, and I thought we fought extremely hard for 40 minutes. There are a lot of things that we continue to improve, and I thought we improved a lot of those things today. We are about growth right now, so every game and every practice is instrumental for us to continue to make those moves." NOTES AND TEAM STATS Jackson led the team in scoring with 10 points on the night. Onugha and Simmons were close behind with nine apiece. Onugha narrowly missed her second double-double of the season, leading the team on the glass with nine boards. The Owls outshot the Gators from the line, 76.9 percent to 73.1 percent. Florida Atlantic won the possession game, outpacing the Gators in steals, collecting 13 to Florida's six. Moors led the Owls in this category, collecting a game-high five steals. The Owls also bested the Gators on the offensive glass, 15 to 14, and forced Florida into more turnovers, 21 to 19. UP NEXT The Owls kick off the Thanksgiving Classic inside Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena on Thursday, Nov. 27, at 12 p.m., where they will face off against Air Force on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic women's basketball, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Flagler Credit Union.

column1: Florida Atlantic Takes Sunshine Slam Semifinal
column2: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. – Florida Atlantic's men's basketball team is heading to the Sunshine Slam's championship game after defeating Loyola Marymount by a score of 64-52 on Monday night at the Ocean Center. The Owls (5-1) delivered the Lions' (6-1) their first loss of the season in the tournament's semifinal matchup behind junior guard Kanaan Carlyle's second consecutive 20-point outing and redshirt sophomore Devin Vanterpool with another all-around performance highlighted by his 14 points and a relentless defensive effort. FIRST HALF The Owls jumped out to an early lead with Carlyle, whose momentum carried over from the previous game, with a four-point play three minutes in. FAU's lead grew to as much as 13 before LMU went on a run to close the gap to four. An offensive drought was ended by a ferocious driving dunk from Xander Pintelon, part of a perfect first half from the field for the junior forward. The hot shooting start continued up to the final buzzer, with Vanterpool drilling an attempt from beyond the arc in the closing seconds to send the Owls into the locker room with a 41-34 lead. SECOND HALF LMU worked its way back into the game, cutting the deficit to four in the opening minutes of the final period. The Owls never surrendered the lead, responding with a 12-2 run over the course of four minutes to go up by 11. The Lions had one more run in them to trail by two with just under 10 minutes remaining, but Florida Atlantic soon built its lead back up to double digits, this time from attacking the paint. An explosive sequence by Vanterpool on both ends of the floor ensued, soaring for a two-handed block to deny a dunk attempt despite a four-inch height disadvantage, and then swishing a step-back jumper. It was all FAU the rest of the way, surrendering just two field goals to the Lions in the final five minutes. PRESS CONFERENCE GALLERY Gallery: (11-24-2025) MBB vs. LMU STATS & NOTES For the third time in four seasons, Florida Atlantic has won four out of its first five games. The Owls have not trailed at any point in their last four victories. With 24 points, Carlyle reached a new FAU career high for the second straight game. Redshirt sophomore forward Devin Williams, the team's leader in blocks, totaled three in the first half and finished the night with a career high of four. Pintelon hauled in nine rebounds, the most by an Owl on the season. The team won the rebounding battle over the Lions 42-29. UP NEXT The champion of the Sunshine Slam's Beach Bracket will be determined in the matchup between Florida Atlantic and George Mason on Tuesday, Nov. 25, at 7:30 p.m. on CBS Sports Network. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

column1: Owls’ Comeback Comes Up Short in Sunshine Slam Title Game
column2: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. – The Florida Atlantic men's basketball team erased a 19-point second half deficit but ultimately fell to George Mason, 74-65, in the Sunshine Slam championship game on Tuesday evening at the Ocean Center. In the title game for the 2025 Sunshine Slam's Beach Bracket, the Owls (5-2) embarked on a 12-0 run over the Patriots (7-0) with less than 11 minutes remaining, bringing the game within one possession multiple times in the final moments. Redshirt sophomore guard Devin Vanterpool was once again an FAU spark plug, scoring 17 points on 6-for-9 shooting to go with his team-best nine rebounds and five assists to earn a spot on the Sunshine Slam's All-Tournament team. FIRST HALF The Owls' early offensive success came from three-point range, with the first nine points coming from beyond the arc. Junior guard Kanaan Carlyle and Devin Vanterpool combined for 21 of the team's 25 points. Florida Atlantic closed the gap on the double-digit deficit, trailing by nine with one minute remaining, before two straight triples from George Mason sent the Owls into the locker room trailing 40-25. SECOND HALF Leaning on the inside game to start the final period, the Owls converted seven of their first 11 attempts, all coming from the paint. With under 11 minutes remaining, the Patriots took a game-high 19-point lead. Then, the Florida Atlantic comeback was on, going on its 12-0 run while holding George Mason without a field goal for nearly five minutes. The Owls' gap continued to close, led by Vanterpool and redshirt freshman guard Amar Amkou, who checked in for the first time of the night with 12 minutes to go and scored seven points. Vanterpool attacked the rim and converted a three-point play to bring the game within single digits, followed by an Amkou layup off a George Mason turnover to cut the lead to three points at the two-minute mark. Redshirt sophomore forward Devin Williams tipped in a missed shot to put the game within one possession once again with 38 seconds left, but the Patriots converted six free throws down the stretch to end the valiant comeback effort. PRESS CONFERENCE STATS & NOTES Carlyle led the way in scoring with 22 points, the first Owl to record 20+ in three straight games since Vlad Goldin in 2024. Vanterpool's nine rebounds are a new career high. He has recorded at least five in each of the first seven games. With three on the night, Williams had his fourth consecutive game with at least three blocks. He has recorded multiple in six out of seven games on the season. The Owls outscored the Patriots 38-26 in the paint. UP NEXT Florida Atlantic will close out the month of November by hosting St. Bonaventure on the 30th at 3:30 p.m. at Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena on ESPN2. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date on all things FAU men's basketball, follow the Owls on social media @FAUMBB. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Phil Smith Kia/Phil Smith Acura.

column1: Second-Half Surge Powers Owls Past Air Force
column2: BOCA RATON, Fla. – A big second-half surge helped to lead the Florida Atlantic Owls past the Air Force Falcons, 76-71, on Thursday at Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. The Owls improve to 3-3 overall, and Air Force falls to 3-4 on the season. HOW IT HAPPENED Air Force opened the contest on an 8-4 run, but the Owls answered back with an 8-4 run of their own, capped off by Vivian Onugha's first basket of the day, to tie things up at 12-12 with just under three minutes remaining in the first. FAU took the lead at 17-14, but an Air Force triple tied the back-and-forth contest at 17-all to close the first. The Falcons retook the lead to open the second, 21-17. Destyne Jackson brought the Owls back within two at 21-17 at the 7:40-minute mark. Air Force capitalized on numerous FAU errors as the Falcons went on a 13-4 run to hold a 13-point lead with 2:37 to go in the half. Air Force maintained its 13-point lead through the final minutes of the opening half until Jess Moors knocked down her first triple of the day to cut the deficit to 10 before the break at 36-26. The Owls refocused at the half, turning the tide in the third period. Capitalizing on numerous Air Force turnovers, FAU produced a dominant 19-7 run, capped off by a triple from Madi Gewirtz, to retake the lead 45-43. Zahira Arizmendi hit her first triple of the day to extend the Owls' lead to five, 50-45, but the Falcons closed the quarter with a three to cut the Owls' lead to 55-53. A pair of Air Force free throws tied things up at 55 to open the fourth, but the Owls responded with a 9-2 run to build their lead back to seven, 64-57, with 5:35 to play. The Falcons went on another run, outscoring the Owls 8-4, cutting the lead to three, 68-65, with just under three minutes to play. However, a layup from Moors and back-to-back free throws from Haley Walker and Moors pushed the Owls' lead back to eight, 74-66, with 24 seconds remaining. The Owls maintained their advantage, but a late Air Force triple closed out the 76-71 contest in favor of the Owls. HEAR FROM HEAD COACH LEANN FREELAND "I felt like we fought really hard to get back in the game. We started out extremely flat, which I believe is due to the physicality of the game on Monday, so we had to get refocused at half. Our full-court pressure definitely got us back in the game and enabled us to force the turnovers we needed to score some easy buckets. NOTES AND TEAM STATS Three Owls finished in double figures in the win. Moors led the way for the Owls with a team-high 15 points, shooting 57 percent (4-of-7) from the field, 50 percent (1-of-2) from 3-point range, and going a perfect 100 percent (6-of-6) at the line. Moors also dished out a team-best three assists and collected three steals and a board in the win. Jackson and Onugha rounded out the Owls' double-figure scorers, tallying 14 points apiece. Onugha finished with a team-leading seven boards and added a block in the contest. The Owls had a strong second-half performance, outscoring the Falcons 40-35 in the final two periods. FAU outshot Air Force at all three levels, outpacing the Falcons from the field, 59.6 to 44.6 percent, from beyond the arc, 50 to 42.1 percent, and at the line, 78.9 to 76.5 percent. The Owls also outrebounded the Falcons, holding a 29-23 advantage on the glass. UP NEXT The Owls have a short turnaround as they get ready for a Friday matchup against the Wright State Raiders. Tipoff is scheduled for 1 p.m. on ESPN+ inside Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic women's basketball, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Flagler Credit Union.

column1: Owls Win Overtime Thriller Over Wright State
column2: BOCA RATON, Fla. – The Florida Atlantic women's basketball team completed the comeback to win an overtime thriller 66-65 over the Wright State Raiders at Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena on Friday. The Owls improve to 4-3 overall, while Wright State falls to 4-4 on the season. HOW IT HAPPENED A slow start saw the Owls fall behind 9-2 over the first six minutes of play. Michiyah Simmons started to get the offense going with a 3-pointer a minute later, 9-5, and a layup from Jess Moors off a steal made it a two-point game, 9-7, at the 3:23-minute mark. The Owls kept things within two to close the first quarter, 11-9. FAU continued to trail into the second quarter, keeping it close at 13-12 through the seven-minute mark. However, Wright State began to pull away, going up by six points at 18-12. Grace Carstensen got her first points of the game, starting a 5-0 run to bring Florida Atlantic within a point, 18-17. But the Raiders responded, going on a 6-0 run of their own to close out the half to make it a 24-17 ballgame at the break. Madi Gewirtz opened the scoring in the third, knocking down a pair of free throws, 24-19. Wright State then went on an 11-5 run to extend its lead to as much as 11, 35-24, through the 6:08-minute mark. However, the Owls fought back, combined a pair of runs, a 5-0 run, followed by an 8-0 run, to make it a one-possession game, 39-37, entering the final 10 minutes of play. Wright State extended its lead back to five, 42-37, after a trio of free throws to start the fourth. Vivian Onugha led the comeback for the Owls, contributing seven points to put Florida Atlantic ahead by two for their first lead of the game at 46-44. The back-and-forth battle continued, with Jess Moors tying it up in the final seconds to send the game into overtime tied at 56. The back-and-forth battle continued into overtime. The Owls took the lead 58-56 to open overtime after a pair of free throws from Gewirtz, but the Raiders answered back on an 8-1 run to retake a five-point lead, 64-59. FAU fought back on a 6-1 run, capped off by a Simmons three, to tie things up once again at 65 with 23 seconds to play. Carstensen put the owls up by one with six seconds to go off a free throw. Wright State had the final possession, but Moors intercepted the inbound pass to close out the final seconds and seal the Owls' 66-65 win. HEAR FROM HEAD COACH LEANN FREELAND I'm really proud of our effort today. It was a complete team win. I thought we fought for 45 minutes. Even though it wasn't pretty offensively, I thought we had a great defensive effort and followed the game plan extremely well. We had some big plays down the stretch, Jess Moors' layup in transition to put us into overtime, and then her steal late came up huge. Also, Michiyah Simmons, I thought she had some big plays offensively to keep us in the game. But overall, a great team win, and really proud of this team for continuing to fight and never giving in." NOTES AND TEAM STATS Three Owls finished in double digits on the day. Destyne Jackson and Simmons each had a team-high 12 points. Jackson shot 42 percent (5-of-12) from the field and 29 percent (2-of-7) from beyond the arc, while Simmons shot 33 percent (3-of-9) from the field, 40 percent (2-of-5) from 3-point range, and went a perfect 100 percent (4-of-4) at the line. Gewirtz rounded out the Owls' double-figure scorers, finishing with 11 points, shooting 75 percent (3-of-4) from the field and going a perfect 100 percent (5-of-5) at the line. Haley Walker led the team on the glass with 11 rebounds, while Onugha finished second with nine boards in the win. The Owls dominated the Raiders on the boards, outrebounding Wright State 50 to 37, including a 21-11 advantage on the offensive glass. FAU also earned a big advantage in points off the bench as the Owls' reserves outscored Wright State 23 to eight in the win. UP NEXT The Owls head to Bowling Green, Kentucky, to face Western Kentucky on Wednesday, Dec. 3, at 7:30 p.m. at E.A. Diddle Arena and on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic women's basketball, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Flagler Credit Union.

column1: Florida Atlantic Falls in Season Finale
column2: BOCA RATON, FLA. – The Florida Atlantic football team was defeated by East Carolina by a score of 42-3 on Saturday afternoon at Flagler Credit Union Stadium to close the 2025 season. With the clock winding down in the first quarter, redshirt junior WR Easton Messer nearly took a punt return to the house, stepping out of bounds at the Pirates' 10-yard line after cutting across the field for 60 yards. The Owls (4-8, 3-5) settled for a field goal by redshirt senior kicker Garrison Smith for their only points of the afternoon before holding ECU (8-4, 6-2) scoreless in the second half. As part of a Senior Day ceremony, the following players were recognized pregame: DL Kiemar Brown-Richardson, WR Jett Coolman, DB Daniel Johnson, DB Chris Keys Jr., TE Michael Kirch, LS Jackson Lee, P Logan Lupo, WR Devarius Mitchell, DB Terez Reid, K Garrison Smith, OL Michael Unis, OL Scarlee Jean, DB Wendol Philord, DL Bryce Langston, and OL Alex Atcavage. VIDEO RECAP OFFENSE With 10 receptions for 86 yards, redshirt junior WR Easton Messer finishes the season with 104 catches and 1,052 receiving yards. He is just the second Owl to record 100+ receptions in a season and finishes third all-time in single season receiving yards in program history. Redshirt junior Caden Veltkamp and graduate QB Zach Gibson combined for 299 passing yards. They logged 275+ yards through the air in all 12 games of the 2025 season, the first Owl offense to accomplish this in program history. DEFENSE Redshirt junior LB Tyler Stolsky led the way with 12 tackles. It was his fifth game in 2025 to record 12+, putting him in elite company with Azeez Al-Shaair as the last Owl to do so in one season. Following Stolsky's lead, redshirt junior LB Leon Hart Jr. added nine tackles to finish the year with 97. He and Stolsky are the first Florida Atlantic duo since Rashad Smith and Akileis Leroy in 2019 to each have 90+ tackles in a season. With five on the afternoon, redshirt senior DB Dillion Williams reached 100 career tackles. Freshman DE Josh Roberts notched a sack, his third of the season, and forced a fumble in the process. SPECIAL TEAMS Messer's 60-yard punt return was the fourth longest in school history. He set the single-season program record in average yards per punt return (minimum 10 attempts) at 20.8. Redshirt senior kicker Garrison Smith finishes the season converting 84% (16-for-19) of his field goal attempts, the highest in one season in program history. He connected with all 36 of his extra point attempts, making him a perfect 108-for-108 in his collegiate career. The Owls have not missed a kicked point after touchdown since 2021. POSTGAME AUDIO Hagerty Family Head Football Coach Zach Kittley Redshirt Junior WR Easton Messer Redshirt Senior DB Terez Reid vs ECU PHOTO GALLERY Gallery: (11-29-2025) ECU at Florida Atlantic FOLLOW ON SOCIAL Stay informed by reading FAUSports.com or through social media accounts @FAUFootball.

column1: Owls Host Bonnies for First of Home-and-Home Series
column2: BOCA RATON, Fla. – The Florida Atlantic men's basketball team returns to Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena to host St. Bonaventure on Sunday, Nov. 30. Tipoff is at 3:30 p.m. on ESPN2. Fresh off an appearance in the Sunshine Slam championship, the Owls (5-2) will take on the Bonnies (6-1) for the second time in three years and for the first matchup of a home-and-home series, with FAU traveling to St. Bonaventure the following season. The afternoon will mark Boy Scouts Day at The Elly, presented by Phil Smith Kia. For troops that wish to attend the game, click here for a limited number of discounted tickets. This game is also part of the Hometown Team Feast Week ticket deal. LAST TIME OUT Participating in the four-team Sunshine Slam's Beach Bracket in Daytona Beach, the Owls defeated LMU by a score of 76-65 before falling in the championship game to George Mason, 74-65. Junior guard Kanaan Carlyle recorded back-to-back 20+ point outings while redshirt sophomore guard Devin Vanterpool averaged 15.5 points to go with 8.0 rebounds per game and 3.5 assists on his way to being named to the all-tournament team. ABOUT THE OWLS Head Coach John Jakus is in his second season at the helm of the program. In his debut campaign in 2024-25, he was a finalist for the Joe B. Hall Award, given to the nation's top first-year head coach. Under Jakus' watch, the Owls participated in their fourth straight year of postseason play, selected to the 2025 National Invitational Tournament. FAU boasts eight international players. In total, the Owls are represented by seven different countries: the United States, Canada, Germany, Italy, Belgium, Senegal, and France. Returning for the Owls are Vanterpool, redshirt junior guard Niccolo Moretti, and redshirt freshman guards Amar Amkou, Liam Dayco-Green, and Max Langenfeld. The Owls welcome 10 newcomers: four true freshmen, four from the transfer portal, and two international players. Carlyle has reached the 20+ point mark in three consecutive games, the first Florida Atlantic player to do so since Vlad Goldin in March of 2024. He leads the team at 16.6 points per game. Vanterpool has had a career-best start to the season, second on FAU in points per game (16.0), while leading in rebounds per game (6.9), assists per game (3.3), and steals (1.4). Against Coastal Georgia, he scored 30 points, the first Owl since Johnell Davis in January of 2024. The Owls are 12th in the nation in blocks per game (6.0). Leading the category individually is redshirt sophomore forward Devin Williams at 2.6 per game. He has recorded multiple in six out of seven appearances. Guard Josiah Parker was named the American Conference's Preseason Freshman of the Year. Florida Atlantic was ranked sixth in the American's preseason poll. ABOUT THE BONNIES Mark Schmidt is in his 19th season with the program, tied for the 13th-longest current tenure among Division I head coaches. The Bonnies are led by Darryl "Buddy" Simmons II. The 5'11 junior guard is averaging a team-best 16.9 points per game while shooting 40.5% from three-point range. Frank Mitchell, a senior transfer forward previously at Minnesota, is top 30 in the country in rebounds per game at 10.1 As a team, the Bonnies are averaging 5.7 blocks per game, tied for 18th nationwide. St. Bonaventure's lone loss this season has come against nationally ranked North Carolina. The Owls and the Bonnies last faced off in December of 2023, with FAU winning by a score of 64-54 to even the all-time series at 1-1. St. Bonaventure won the first meeting in 2019. UP NEXT Florida Atlantic will make the short trip to Fort Myers to play Florida Gulf Coast on Sunday, Dec. 7. Tipoff is at 2 p.m. on ESPN+. SCHEDULE Click here for the 2025-26 schedule. column1: Owls Win Overtime Thriller Over Wright State
column2: BOCA RATON, Fla. – The Florida Atlantic women's basketball team completed the comeback to win an overtime thriller 66-65 over the Wright State Raiders at Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena on Friday. The Owls improve to 4-3 overall, while Wright State falls to 4-4 on the season. HOW IT HAPPENED A slow start saw the Owls fall behind 9-2 over the first six minutes of play. Michiyah Simmons started to get the offense going with a 3-pointer a minute later, 9-5, and a layup from Jess Moors off a steal made it a two-point game, 9-7, at the 3:23-minute mark. The Owls kept things within two to close the first quarter, 11-9. FAU continued to trail into the second quarter, keeping it close at 13-12 through the seven-minute mark. However, Wright State began to pull away, going up by six points at 18-12. Grace Carstensen got her first points of the game, starting a 5-0 run to bring Florida Atlantic within a point, 18-17. But the Raiders responded, going on a 6-0 run of their own to close out the half to make it a 24-17 ballgame at the break. Madi Gewirtz opened the scoring in the third, knocking down a pair of free throws, 24-19. Wright State then went on an 11-5 run to extend its lead to as much as 11, 35-24, through the 6:08-minute mark. However, the Owls fought back, combined a pair of runs, a 5-0 run, followed by an 8-0 run, to make it a one-possession game, 39-37, entering the final 10 minutes of play. Wright State extended its lead back to five, 42-37, after a trio of free throws to start the fourth. Vivian Onugha led the comeback for the Owls, contributing seven points to put Florida Atlantic ahead by two for their first lead of the game at 46-44. The back-and-forth battle continued, with Jess Moors tying it up in the final seconds to send the game into overtime tied at 56. The back-and-forth battle continued into overtime. The Owls took the lead 58-56 to open overtime after a pair of free throws from Gewirtz, but the Raiders answered back on an 8-1 run to retake a five-point lead, 64-59. FAU fought back on a 6-1 run, capped off by a Simmons three, to tie things up once again at 65 with 23 seconds to play. Carstensen put the owls up by one with six seconds to go off a free throw. Wright State had the final possession, but Moors intercepted the inbound pass to close out the final seconds and seal the Owls' 66-65 win. HEAR FROM HEAD COACH LEANN FREELAND I'm really proud of our effort today. It was a complete team win. I thought we fought for 45 minutes. Even though it wasn't pretty offensively, I thought we had a great defensive effort and followed the game plan extremely well. We had some big plays down the stretch, Jess Moors' layup in transition to put us into overtime, and then her steal late came up huge. Also, Michiyah Simmons, I thought she had some big plays offensively to keep us in the game. But overall, a great team win, and really proud of this team for continuing to fight and never giving in." NOTES AND TEAM STATS Three Owls finished in double digits on the day. Destyne Jackson and Simmons each had a team-high 12 points. Jackson shot 42 percent (5-of-12) from the field and 29 percent (2-of-7) from beyond the arc, while Simmons shot 33 percent (3-of-9) from the field, 40 percent (2-of-5) from 3-point range, and went a perfect 100 percent (4-of-4) at the line. Gewirtz rounded out the Owls' double-figure scorers, finishing with 11 points, shooting 75 percent (3-of-4) from the field and going a perfect 100 percent (5-of-5) at the line. Haley Walker led the team on the glass with 11 rebounds, while Onugha finished second with nine boards in the win. The Owls dominated the Raiders on the boards, outrebounding Wright State 50 to 37, including a 21-11 advantage on the offensive glass. FAU also earned a big advantage in points off the bench as the Owls' reserves outscored Wright State 23 to eight in the win. UP NEXT The Owls head to Bowling Green, Kentucky, to face Western Kentucky on Wednesday, Dec. 3, at 7:30 p.m. at E.A. Diddle Arena and on ESPN+. column1: Second-Half Surge Powers Owls Past Air Force
column2: BOCA RATON, Fla. – A big second-half surge helped to lead the Florida Atlantic Owls past the Air Force Falcons, 76-71, on Thursday at Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. The Owls improve to 3-3 overall, and Air Force falls to 3-4 on the season. HOW IT HAPPENED Air Force opened the contest on an 8-4 run, but the Owls answered back with an 8-4 run of their own, capped off by Vivian Onugha's first basket of the day, to tie things up at 12-12 with just under three minutes remaining in the first. FAU took the lead at 17-14, but an Air Force triple tied the back-and-forth contest at 17-all to close the first. The Falcons retook the lead to open the second, 21-17. Destyne Jackson brought the Owls back within two at 21-17 at the 7:40-minute mark. Air Force capitalized on numerous FAU errors as the Falcons went on a 13-4 run to hold a 13-point lead with 2:37 to go in the half. Air Force maintained its 13-point lead through the final minutes of the opening half until Jess Moors knocked down her first triple of the day to cut the deficit to 10 before the break at 36-26. The Owls refocused at the half, turning the tide in the third period. Capitalizing on numerous Air Force turnovers, FAU produced a dominant 19-7 run, capped off by a triple from Madi Gewirtz, to retake the lead 45-43. Zahira Arizmendi hit her first triple of the day to extend the Owls' lead to five, 50-45, but the Falcons closed the quarter with a three to cut the Owls' lead to 55-53. A pair of Air Force free throws tied things up at 55 to open the fourth, but the Owls responded with a 9-2 run to build their lead back to seven, 64-57, with 5:35 to play. The Falcons went on another run, outscoring the Owls 8-4, cutting the lead to three, 68-65, with just under three minutes to play. However, a layup from Moors and back-to-back free throws from Haley Walker and Moors pushed the Owls' lead back to eight, 74-66, with 24 seconds remaining. The Owls maintained their advantage, but a late Air Force triple closed out the 76-71 contest in favor of the Owls. HEAR FROM HEAD COACH LEANN FREELAND "I felt like we fought really hard to get back in the game. We started out extremely flat, which I believe is due to the physicality of the game on Monday, so we had to get refocused at half. Our full-court pressure definitely got us back in the game and enabled us to force the turnovers we needed to score some easy buckets. NOTES AND TEAM STATS Three Owls finished in double figures in the win. Moors led the way for the Owls with a team-high 15 points, shooting 57 percent (4-of-7) from the field, 50 percent (1-of-2) from 3-point range, and going a perfect 100 percent (6-of-6) at the line. Moors also dished out a team-best three assists and collected three steals and a board in the win. Jackson and Onugha rounded out the Owls' double-figure scorers, tallying 14 points apiece. Onugha finished with a team-leading seven boards and added a block in the contest. The Owls had a strong second-half performance, outscoring the Falcons 40-35 in the final two periods. FAU outshot Air Force at all three levels, outpacing the Falcons from the field, 59.6 to 44.6 percent, from beyond the arc, 50 to 42.1 percent, and at the line, 78.9 to 76.5 percent. The Owls also outrebounded the Falcons, holding a 29-23 advantage on the glass. UP NEXT The Owls have a short turnaround as they get ready for a Friday matchup against the Wright State Raiders. Tipoff is scheduled for 1 p.m. on ESPN+ inside Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. BOCA RATON, Fla. – Florida Atlantic football has begun its roster construction for 2026, year two under Hagerty Family Head Football Coach Zach Kittley. Ahead of the upcoming signing day for incoming freshmen, the Owls have additionally added RB Leonard Farrow from Division II Fairmont State. Farrow bolsters the running back room after an all-conference 2025 season in which he finished fifth in all of D2 with 1,438 rushing yards on 178 attempts, picking up 8.1 yards-per-carry. He scored 14 total touchdowns, 12 of them on the ground. His most recent campaign saw him record single game career highs in rushing yards (274), touchdowns (two) and long rush (95). He has totaled 2,652 total yards and 26 touchdowns in three seasons of play. From Mount Hope, West Virginia, Farrow played at Oak Hill High School where he was first-team All-State. FOLLOW THE TEAM Stay informed by reading FAUSports.com or through football's social media accounts @FAUFootball.

BOCA RATON, Fla. – Week 12 of the 2025 NFL season is in the books with four former Florida Atlantic Owls seeing action. Here's a rundown of how each performed during the 12th week (All gametimes listed below are Eastern): Active Owls (4) #0 Azeez Al-Shaair | LB | Houston Texans - Al-Shaair racked up tackles at a high rate on a Thursday night matchup against the Buffalo Bills, notching seven. He added a quarterback hit and pass breakup while playing 100% of the team's defensive snaps for the sixth straight game, the longest stretch of his career without missing a play. The Texans picked up a key 23-19 victory over Buffalo. Texans' Record: 6-5 Next Game: at Indianapolis – Sunday, 1 p.m. (CBS) #84 Zaire Mitchell-Paden | TE | New Orleans Saints - Mitchell-Paden and the Saints returned from their bye week against their divisional rival Atlanta Falcons. He saw the field for 20 total snaps, including a season high 13 on special teams, as New Orleans fell by a score of 24-10. Saints' Record: 2-9 Next Game: at Miami – Sunday, 1 p.m. (FOX) #42 James Pierre | CB | Pittsburgh Steelers - Pierre made his second straight start and recorded three tackles. He also added a pass deflection as Pittsburgh was defeated by a score of 31-28 to the Chicago Bears. Steelers' Record: 6-5 Next Game: vs. Buffalo – Sunday, 4:25 p.m. (CBS) #26 Devin Singletary | RB | New York Giants - "Motor" was a key part of the Giants' run game, carrying the ball 14 times for a season high 47 yards. Singletary ran for two first downs with a long of 13, as New York fell in an overtime thriller to the Detroit Lions by a score of 34-27. Giants' Record: 2-10 Next Game: at New England – Monday, 8:15 p.m. (ESPN) Inactive (1) #91 Trey Hendrickson | DE | Cincinnati Bengals Bengals' Record: 3-8 Next Game: at Baltimore – Thursday, 8:20 p.m. (NBC) Injured Reserve (1) #88 Harrison Bryant | TE | Houston Texans Practice Squad (4) #58 Evan Anderson | DT | San Francisco 49ers #34 Greg Joseph | K | Las Vegas Raiders #62 Federico Maranges | C | Seattle Seahawks #73 Brandon Walton | OT | Carolina Panthers Check fausports.com each Thursday to see how each Owl did the previous week along with a preview of their respective team's next game.

column1: Inside the Owl Burrow S10, Episode 16
column2: BOCA RATON, Fla. – Florida Atlantic football concludes its 25th season celebration with this week's edition of Inside the Owls' Burrow, the final show of 2025. Episode 16 of Inside the Owls' Burrow's 2025 football season, solely produced and hosted by Frank Forte, will air at 1 p.m., on Thursday, Nov. 27 where it will originate on FanDuel Sports Network Florida. It will re-air Saturday, Nov. 29 at 11:30 a.m. The weekly show's 16th installment of the fall will feature Forte talking one-on-one with first-year Hagerty Family Head Football Coach Zach Kittley about the Owls' electric contest versus UConn and the upcoming American home contest with East Carolina, where the game will air on ESPN+ with the local call provided by on Fox Sports 640 AM South Florida. The game is slated for 12 p.m. Forte will look back at 25 years of Owl football at the outstanding career of defensive end Trey Hendrickson, "Where are they Now" visits with a member of the original Owls' team, Kinyumba Mutakabbir, whose current profession is acting. The show will also hear from Wide Receivers Coach DJ McCarthy on the career years for each of the four of his main receivers. The show will conclude with a look at the most interesting and impactful plays of the 2025 season. Inside the Owls' Burrow is also available at www.fausports.com and on YouTube.
